children.title: Definition of Business
Business refers to human activities directed towards producing or acquiring wealth through buying and selling goods.
Economic and Non-Economic Activities
Economic: Activities done to earn money (e.g., business, profession, employment).
Non-Economic: Activities done out of love, sympathy, patriotism, etc.
Business vs. Profession vs. Employment
Business: Production/distribution of goods/services for profit.
Profession: Specialized services for a fee (e.g., doctor, lawyer).
Employment: Working for others for salary/wages.
Industry
Primary: Extractive (agriculture, mining).
Secondary: Manufacturing and construction.
Tertiary: Services (transport, banking, insurance).
Commerce
Trade: Buying and selling of goods.
Aids to Trade: Transport, banking, insurance, warehousing, advertising, communication.
Economic Activity
Business is undertaken to earn money or livelihood.
Production or Procurement of Goods and Services
Goods may be produced or procured from producers for sale.
Sale or Exchange of Goods and Services
There must be sale or exchange of goods/services for value.
Dealing in Goods and Services on a Regular Basis
Business involves regular dealings, not one-time transactions.
Profit Earning
The main purpose is to earn profit.
Uncertainty of Return
Profit is uncertain and depends on many factors.
Element of Risk
Business always involves risk of loss.
Economic Objectives
Earning profit, creating customers, innovation, best use of resources.
Social Objectives
Supplying quality goods, fair prices, employment, social welfare.
Human Objectives
Welfare of employees, development of human resources, participation in management.
National Objectives
Creation of employment, promotion of social justice, contribution to GDP, development of backward areas.
Global Objectives
Raise international business standards, create global employment, contribute to world peace.
Profit is a reward, source of capital, measure of efficiency, and survival.
Profit is necessary for expansion and innovation.
Nature of Business Risks
Risks arise due to uncertainties and are an inherent part of business.
Risks may result in loss or lower profits.
Causes of Business Risks
Natural: Floods, earthquakes, etc.
Human: Carelessness, strikes, theft, etc.
Economic: Price changes, competition, demand fluctuations.
Other: Political instability, legal changes, etc.
Ways to Minimize Risks
Insurance, diversification, careful planning, safety measures.
Provides goods and services, creates employment, improves standard of living, supports social causes.
